Principles of Geology.intro: Published in 1830 by the respected firm of John Murray in London, Lyell’s first book, Principles of Geology became a literary classic of the Victorian era. It was here that Lyell argued that the present is the key to the past, ie., that previously formed geological formations can be explained by uniformly-slowly-moving processes acting today, operating over very long periods of time. In three volumes, Principles was not just a one-off publication; he would produce eleven modified and updated versions, filled with new evidence and knowledge accumulated during his life. The twelfth edition was published posthumously in 1875. A particularly useful feature for the historian in the first edition of volume one is the inclusion in chapters 2-4 of the earliest history of geology in the English language.

Elements of Geology.intro: Between the fifth and sixth editions of Principles, the first edition of Elements of Geology was issued in 1838, with an amazingly large print run of 3,500 copies. Regarded in parts as an expansion of volume four of Principles, in Elements, Lyell developed his metamorphic theory of how - with gradual mountain uplift - igneous and metamorphic rocks were formed. In its third edition, in 1851, the title changed to A Manual of Elementary Geology, and in the preface, Lyell makes it clear that Principles is concerned with modern changes of the Earth and its inhabitants, whereas the Manual is concerned with the measurement of ancient changes. In 1865 the title reverted to Elements of Geology - Lyell considered it too long to be classed as a manual. It would prove to be the textbook of its time.
mainContent: A remarkable survival, these 294 notebooks span Lyell’s long scientific career (1825-1874), offering an unrivalled insight into personal influences, field observations, thoughts and relationships. These notebooks were acquired in 2019 thanks to a fundraising campaign, with many generous individual and institutional donors from the UK and overseas. Highlights include his travels throughout Europe and the United States of America, the drafts of his correspondence with the likes of Charles Darwin, his geological and landscape sketches and his constant gathering of evidence and refinement of his theories.

Watch Charles Withers, Emeritus Professor of Geography at the University of Edinburgh, discussing the importance of Lyell's Note Books and how they relate to current issues of deep time and climate change in the short film 'The Travels Of His Own Mind,' made by Malcolm Brown, Digital Imaging Unit.

American travelogues.intro:
Between 1841 and 1853, Charles and Mary Lyell went to North America four times, after Lyell was invited to deliver a series of lectures there. They travelled by various means, steamboat, horseback, stagecoach, journeying from the Atlantic coast to Ohio and Mississippi Rivers, and from the St Lawrence Valley to the Gulf Coast, including Massachusetts, Connecticut New York, Virginia, Georgia, the Midwest and Nova Scotia. As Lyell says in the preface, this work ‘embraces a great variety of subjects to which my thoughts were turned during my travels in North America”.
In touring Northern and Southern States, Charles and Mary Lyell were confronted with the deep entrenchment of American plantation slavery in the economy, politics, and social opinion. The Lyells came to America opposed to slavery. They returned with empathy for the plantation owners who hosted them during their stay. Antiquity of Man.intro: The Geological Evidences of the Antiquity of Man, published 1863, is Lyell’s third most important work, and appeared in response to the great interest in human ancestry stimulated four years earlier by Darwin’s Origins of Species (1859) and the immense periods of geological time implied in Principles. Here, Lyell was careful to present evidence, allowing readers to draw their own conclusions - and between 1860 and 1861 he visited important sites in the UK and Europe to gather evidence, documented in his notebooks. Lyell is credited with contributing to the creation, or at least the foundation, of both Prehistoric Archaeology, and Paleoanthropology.
